node.title: Question about the getNeighborADMaterialProperty method
node.bodyText:
Hi all, I want to know I can get the material property of which element if I use the getNeighborADMaterialProperty method?
1D mesh for example?
Ethan

Hello
getNeighborMaterialProperty is to be used in the context of side integrations on interfaces / within-domain boundaries.
the neighbor element is on the other (exterior) side of the sideset, sidesets are oriented.
Guillaume

Thanks Giud. In THM, getNeighborMaterialProperty is used in ADNumericalFlux3EqnDGKernel to calculate the flux between elements. But I'm confused.
As my understanding, for example, a 1D mesh which has 10 elements. Its id is from 0 to 9. If I use getNeighborMaterialProperty in elem0, I will get the material property of elem1, in elem1 and get mat prop of elem2, right? If so, what will I get if I use it in the last element?

DGKernels also consider sides of elements.
So it s not on elem0, it s on elem0 and side "1" (for example)
@Ethan-xj DGKernels never operate on external boundaries
I got it. Thank you all :)

node.title: Compute Polynomial Chaos Expansion Coefficients with Regression
node.bodyText: I am trying to train a PCE surrogate that has too many dimensions to find the coefficients with quadrature. The documentation for the PCE trainer says that regression can be used to find the coefficients, but when I specify regression_type for the PCE trainer it is not recognized as a valid parameter.

node.title: Moose way of representing units for various quantities
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
Just thought of clarifying my ambiguities associated with addressing units in moose for various quantities used in the computation. I am aware these are revolving mainly around the SI units as can be seen here.).
Going by that, is it a valid statement that i address stresses by Pa, assuming that the length scale moose uses is 'meter' and force in kgm/s^2.
The main intention behind my question being that i am struggling to find the units for some of the constants mentioned in https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/crystal_plasticity/CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate.html#!, but unable to find descriptions in the parameters section. The t_sat in that case would be literally called as 109.8 Pa if i am right.
Kind regards,
Arun

Hi @abarun22,
The crystal plasticity classes deviate from the unit-agnostic approach taken by default in MOOSE. As described under the section Units Assumed in Crystal Plasticity Materials on the Compute Multiple Crystal Plasticity Stress documentation page, the crystal plasticity models use the mm-MPa-s unit system. In addition to the documentation page, we have tried to explicitly list the assumed units in the parameter description.
It does look like the Kalidindi model you are referencing does not list those unit assumptions in the parameter descriptions. While we work on updating that documentation, please know that that units for that class is also in the mm-MPa-s system.
Hope this helps,
Stephanie

Thanks Stephanie. That's really what i am after.
Best regards,
Arun

node.title: [PorousFlow] can I use PorousFlowUnsaturated (action) and PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG at the same time?
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
I'd like to use PorousFlowUnsaturated due to simplicity but I want to specify 'van Genuchten' properties (alpha and m) at different domains
PorousFlowUnsaturated  only allows me to assign alpha and m once homogenously which is not ideal
so if I have this block [PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG] in the input file, will this overwrite the default values of alpha and m defined in [PorousFlowUnsaturated] ?

or of there is another way please let me know
Thank you!
Kind regards,
Traiwit

Adding an extra userobject won't work as the PorousFlowUnsaturated action hard codes the capillary pressure user object name.
I think that you will need to add all of the objects that the action creates by hand to do what you want unfortunately.

I see, thank you @cpgr
just wondering if alpha and m in PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG can be assigned based on _qp (element based property)?
It looks like it can, but everything i can fine related to alpha and m so far are Real single value
  _m(getParam<Real>("m")),
   _alpha(getParam<Real>("alpha")),

No. They can be block-specific, though, which is how we tend to use them. Say you have two blocks in your mesh (A and B in your example above). Then you have two capillary pressure user objects, one for each block. You then block restrict the material where they are used, so that block A calls Pc_A, block B calls Pc_B.

You're going to have to add this yourself then - I don't think it can be done with the current code. It shouldn't be hard though - I have done similar for the BC capillary pressure where the entry pressure varies element by element and it works fine.

I see, could you able to share the class you mentioned? otherwise, it's ok
thank you!
The changes are simple if you make _m and _alpha AuxVariables, like what we do for materials like the constant porosity one. Then you can have element-by-element capillary pressures.

Btw if you leverage the functor system for these quantities you will be able to pass/use for them:

functions
Variables, both aux and nonlinear
Functor material properties
And soon
scalar variables
Postprocessors

@GiudGiud, here is the plan, please let me know if it's ok
read m and alpha from .csv
 [VG_parameter]
    type = PropertyReadFile
    prop_file_name = 'VG_parameter.csv'
    nprop = 2
    read_type = element
  []

make it a Material property
  [VG_parameter]
    type = GenericConstantArrayBEH
    prop_name = alpha m    (something alone this line)
    read_prop_user_object = VG_parameter
  []

Q would be, can I then directly input alpha and m into PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG, or I have to make my own PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG class that can take alpha and m
  [pc]
    type = PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG
    m = m
    alpha = alpha 
  []

or _alpha(getMaterialProperty<Real>("alpha")), _m(getMaterialProperty<Real>("m")),  (PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVG.C)
Works for me! So you have a class retrieving with the voronoi algorithm from a prop reader user object?

Yeah, _m is a material property, so you need to use _m[_qp] everywhere in your PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE class. You will have to replace the _pc_scale bit in all the functions with PorousFlowVanGenuchten::capillaryPressure(_s_scale, _alpha, _m[_qp], _pc_max) as you can't compute it in advance anymore as it will change element to element (or just not use this correction if you don't need it).

Hi @cpgr thank you for you suggestion, but I still keep getting new errors after another
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C: In constructor 'PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE::PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE(const InputParameters&)':
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C:45:79: error: '_qp' was not declared in this scope
   45 |     _pc_sscale(PorousFlowVanGenuchten::capillaryPressure(_s_scale, _alpha, _m[_qp], _pc_max))
      |                                                                               ^~~
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C: In member function 'virtual libMesh::Real PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE::capillaryPressureCurve(libMesh::Real, unsigned int) const':
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C:53:69: error: '_qp' was not declared in this scope
   53 |   return PorousFlowVanGenuchten::capillaryPressure(seff, _alpha, _m[_qp], _pc_max) - _pc_sscale;
      |                                                                     ^~~
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C: In member function 'virtual libMesh::Real PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE::dCapillaryPressureCurve(libMesh::Real, unsigned int) const':
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C:60:70: error: '_qp' was not declared in this scope
   60 |   return PorousFlowVanGenuchten::dCapillaryPressure(seff, _alpha, _m[_qp], _pc_max) * _dseff_ds *
      |                                                                      ^~~
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C: In member function 'virtual libMesh::Real PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE::d2CapillaryPressureCurve(libMesh::Real, unsigned int) const':
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C:68:71: error: '_qp' was not declared in this scope
   68 |   return PorousFlowVanGenuchten::d2CapillaryPressure(seff, _alpha, _m[_qp], _pc_max) * _dseff_ds *
      |                                                                       ^~~
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C: In member function 'virtual libMesh::Real PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE::effectiveSaturation(libMesh::Real, unsigned int) const':
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C:76:82: error: '_qp' was not declared in this scope
   76 |          PorousFlowVanGenuchten::effectiveSaturation(pc - _pc_sscale, _alpha, _m[_qp]);
      |                                                                                  ^~~
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C: In member function 'virtual libMesh::Real PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE::dEffectiveSaturation(libMesh::Real, unsigned int) const':
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C:83:83: error: '_qp' was not declared in this scope
   83 |          PorousFlowVanGenuchten::dEffectiveSaturation(pc - _pc_sscale, _alpha, _m[_qp]);
      |                                                                                   ^~~
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C: In member function 'virtual libMesh::Real PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE::d2EffectiveSaturation(libMesh::Real, unsigned int) const':
/home/moose/moose_beh/src/kernels/PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE.C:90:84: error: '_qp' was not declared in this scope
   90 |          PorousFlowVanGenuchten::d2EffectiveSaturation(pc - _pc_sscale, _alpha, _m[_qp]);
      |                                                                                    ^~~

should I need to add something like initQpStatefulProperties to my class?

This was the bit that you can't do this, as qp doesn't exist during construction. I would just remove this bit and all cases of _pc_scale unless you really need it?
Sorry about the typo - I meant qp not _qp!
You don't need to change the function, as _m[qp] should just be a number that you are passing to the function. If you past the actual seg fault message it should help narrow it down.

a very dumb question, how do I do that?
below is all I got
===================================================================================
=   BAD TERMINATION OF ONE OF YOUR APPLICATION PROCESSES
=   PID 403267 RUNNING AT moose-System-Product-Name
=   EXIT CODE: 139
=   CLEANING UP REMAINING PROCESSES
=   YOU CAN IGNORE THE BELOW CLEANUP MESSAGES
===================================================================================
YOUR APPLICATION TERMINATED WITH THE EXIT STRING: Segmentation fault (signal 11)
This typically refers to a problem with your application.
Please see the FAQ page for debugging suggestions

There are some details on the moose website here https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html, but if you paste the complete PorousFlowCapillaryPressureVGBE file here I could hopefully guess what the problem is without you needing to compile a dbg version.

node.title: Increase of a variable residual and convergence issue
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Hope you are well.
I am using PorousFlow module of MOOSE but my question is a bit more general and related to solving the equations. I have turned on the show_var_residual_norms to see the residual for each variable. The thing that I do not understand is that somewhere in the solve, a variable residual increases and causes convergence problem (please see below the residual for tracer variable). I was wondering what is the reason and how I can solve it. Thanks.
Time Step 3, time = 3, dt = 1
0 Nonlinear |R| = 2.211444e-06
|residual|_2 of individual variables:
pwater: 9.11345e-09
satg:   9.16047e-22
tracer: 2.21143e-06
1 Nonlinear |R| = 8.379444e-06
|residual|_2 of individual variables:
pwater: 5.11939e-07
satg:   7.53075e-22
tracer: 8.36379e-06
2 Nonlinear |R| = 6.201440e-05
|residual|_2 of individual variables:
pwater: 3.9068e-06
satg:   5.89635e-22
tracer: 6.18912e-05
3 Nonlinear |R| = 6.116279e-05
|residual|_2 of individual variables:
pwater: 3.41119e-06
satg:   4.76689e-22
tracer: 6.10676e-05
Best regards,
Sina

I would start by reading https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html if you haven't already. Seeing a variable residual increase during an iteration of a Newton solve is not unusual, but if you're unable to run your simulation satisfactorily then there may be issues. Are you using Newton or PJFNK as your solve_type? How are your linear solves?

Hi Alex,
Thanks for sharing the link. I am using Newton as my solver. The linear solve is also slow. I have tested various preconditioning for my problem and only the following setting gave me better results. I have been testing different nl_abs_tol and l_abs_tol to find the one suitable for my problem.
[precond]
type = SMP
full = true
petsc_options = '-snes_linesearch_monitor'
petsc_options_iname = '-snes_type -pc_factor_shift_type -snes_linesearch_type'
petsc_options_value = 'vinewtonssls nonzero l2'
[]
To be honest, I do not know so much about various preconditioning settings, and how I can choose one based on my problem. I also appreciate if you have any suggestion in this regard. Thanks.
What physics are you solving? You have to be solving very special problems in order to use vinewtonssls

I am using PorousFlow and my problem is a multi-component fluid flow in porous media. However, the viscosity is not constant (it is a non-newtonian fluid). As I said, I do not know about the preconditioning and found this one in a tensor mechanics example I think.

@cpgr and @WilkAndy can advise you on good preconditioning settings. For debugging your convergence and ensuring the linear solves aren't the problem, I would suggest changing to
[precond]
  solve_type = NEWTON
  type = SMP
  full = true
  petsc_options = '-snes_linesearch_monitor'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type -snes_linesearch_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu NONZERO basic'
[]
iirc there is a porous flow preconditioning page in the porous flow documentation you should consult

@WilkAndy has provided some good suggestions here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/solvers.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/nonlinear_convergence_problems.html
and also
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/convergence.html

node.title: Designing field-split preconditioners for NS
node.bodyText:
This is meant to be a repository of information for designing field split conditioners for NS. When (or even before) we have options that work robustly for a range of Reynolds numbers, this should go into the MOOSE documentation
My general experience:

Jacobi for the Schur takes more iterations than something like ASM+(I)LU but it is less expensive so it often wins
Apparently boomeramg works better on high Re problems when L is large compared to ASM+(I)LU but ASM+(I)LU works better on high Re problems for small mu. This in reference to solving the momentum part of the matrix
If there is no diagonal, then for Jacobi for Schur, specify -pc_jacobi_type rowmax; -pc_jacobi_type rowsum appears to be terrible. Note that when using the default -pc_jacobi_type diagonal if a 0 is encountered, then 1 is used
Jacobi doesn't work for the momentum part of the matrix; not strong enough
For advection dominated, full factorization does not compare as poorly to lower/upper as for non-advection dominated, in fact it may be faster
I believe for Aij matrices in PETSc that the block size is always 1. So when doing Schur problems, doing Ainv types of diag and blockdiag are equivalent and in these cases when using selfp Ainv just corresponds to the reciprocal of A's diagonal which for advection dominated leads to Sp poorly approximating S, e.g. even when doing first order upwind with a Reynolds number of 2.2 in our 2d-rc-no-slip.i channel flow problem, it takes 50-60 linear iterations to solve the Schur complement with -pc_type lu for both the outer Schur PC type and the A00 PC type
selfp degrades with increasing Reynolds number as the diagonal of A00 is a poor representation of A00
self with LSC preconditioning appears to be promising for stable discretizations (e.g. Q2-Q1 finite elements). It requires some PETSC development (see this MR) in order to have mesh independent scaling. The current PETSc implementation does not add corrections for stabilized discretizations such as PSPG for finite elements or Rhie-Chow for finite volumes. I'll have to see whether that is required

self with LSC is indeed a great preconditioner, especially for stable C0 finite elements. See timing in #24548 (comment). When doing LSC preconditioning with a KSP solve, it is best to limit the number of outer linear solve iterations, e.g. full should be used as the factorization as opposed to upper,lower,diag, since the ksp(S,Sp) will be expensive

Would you be able to share a copy of the code that you used to evaluate and determine you findings a presented above? I would like to run my own test with different geometry and variable values with what you have developed.

You can use this example: https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/navier_stokes/test/tests/finite_volume/ins/channel-flow/2d-rc-no-slip.i
we base most of our studies on this one and on a large scale reactor model we can't share.
I've opened #24883 if you want to follow along with my field split research. That PR includes a finite element example, which I believe you asked about elsewhere

node.title: Kernel Compile problems
node.bodyText:
I am studying the "Babbler" example and trying to add some new kernels in this application, I followed the steps here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial01_app_development/step05_kernel_object.html
I put the .c and .h files in the src and include folder respectively, then run make -j 4. The .C and .h files I want to add are just copied from modules files. I also changed the App name for .C file.

But when I want to run " cd ~/projects/babbler/problems
../babbler-opt -i my_own-project.i  " the kernel I want to add are still not been registered.

Are there any steps missing?

If you want to use classes from a module, you should modify the Makefile in your application, toggling PHASE_FIELD := yes
But with respect to your error, you showed that you registered ADSplitCHWRes, but the error is about the non-AD object SplitCHWRes. Did you register the non-AD version to your app?
I changed the makefile then compile again, but I got this:
Do you still have the copies in your application? I would make sure you've remove the copies and you're only using the phase field module version of that kernel

I remove all the moose files and download them again, I guess there are some problems in the source file. Now It works.
Thank you.

node.title: My SmoothCircleIC has problem
node.bodyText:
Hello, Moose experts.
I applied MultiSmoothCircleIC on the block=2 but something is wrong.

It doesn't have the same value in the circle.
SmoothCircleIC has the same problem as below.

As you can see on the line plot view, the n has from 4 to 10 values.
But my coworker's MultiSmoothCircleIC doesn't have any problem as below.

This is my input file.

########## Global Parameters ########## 
xmax = 30
ymax = 35

Nmax = 10.0

#######################################



[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 6
    ny = 7
    nz = 0
    xmin = 0
    xmax = ${xmax}
    ymin = 0
    ymax = ${ymax}
    zmin = 0
    zmax = 0
    elem_type = QUAD4
  []
  [./blk1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 1                                                                                                                                                                                bottom_left = '0.0  0.000  0.0'
    top_right = '${xmax} 30.00000  0.0'
    block_name = 'reservoir'
    input = gen
  [../]

  [./refine_0]
    type = RefineBlockGenerator
    input = blk1
    block = 0
    refinement = '5'
  [../]

  [./blk2]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 2
    bottom_left = '10.00  30.00  0.0'
    top_right = '20.00 35.00  0.0'
    block_name = 'filament'
    input = refine_0
  [../]

  [./bd1]
    type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
    block = 1
    new_boundary = 'interface'
    normal = '0 1 0'
    input = blk2
  [../]



[]



[Functions]
  [./bc_func]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    data_file = './vsweep.csv'
    format = columns
    scale_factor = 1.0
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  [./N]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]

  [./V]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 0.0
  [../]

  [./T]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 300.0
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  [./N_IC_1]
    type = MultiBoundingBoxIC
    corners = '0.0 0.0 0   '
    opposite_corners = '30.0 30.0 0'
    inside = '${Nmax}'
    outside = '${Nmax}'
    variable = N
    block = 1
  [../]



  [./N_IC_2]
    type = SmoothCircleIC
    invalue = ${Nmax}
    outvalue = 0.0
    radius = 1.5
    variable = N
    x1 = 15
    y1 = 32
    block = 2
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [V_top]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = V
    function = bc_func # GND
    boundary = 'top'
  []


  [V_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = V
    value = 0.0
    boundary = 'bottom'
  []

  [./T_top1]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'top'
    variable = T
    value = 300 #in K
  [../]

  [./T_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'bottom'
    variable = T
    value = 300 #in K
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]

  ########### Phase-field ############

  [./Matdiff_D_del2_N]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = N
    diffusivity = Diff_coeff
  [../]


  [./Nernst]
    type = NernstElec
    variable = N
    elec = V
    eDkT = eDkT
  [../]


  [./PFM_time]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = N
  [../]

  ########## Phase-field END ##########

  ########## Electrical ###############

  [./Matdiff_sig_del2_V]
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = V
    diffusivity = 'electrical_conductivity'
  [../]

  ########## Electrical END ###########

  ###### Heat ######

  [./HeatDiff]
    type = HeatConduction
    variable = T
  [../]

  [./HeatSrc]
    type = JouleHeatingSource
    variable = T
    elec = V
  [../]

  ##################
[]





[Materials]
  [./Diff_coeff]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name  = Diff_coeff
    coupled_variables = 'T'
    constant_names       = 'D0     E_A_D    kB        ' #[nm^2/s]  [eV/K]  [K]
    constant_expressions = '2e+11  1.0      8.617e-5'
    expression = 'D0*exp(-E_A_D/(kB*T))' #[nm^2/s]
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./eDkT]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = eDkT
    coupled_variables = 'T'
    constant_names       = 'kB       ' #[V/K]
    constant_expressions = '8.617e-5'
    material_property_names = 'Diff_coeff'
    expression = 'Diff_coeff/(kB*T)' #[nm^2/(s*V)]
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./electrical_conductivity_INS]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables = 'N E_AC_elec T'
    property_name = 'electrical_conductivity'
    material_property_names = 'sigma_original  sigma_PF'
    expression = 'sigma_original+sigma_PF'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./sigma_original]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables = 'N E_AC_elec T'
    property_name = 'sigma_original'
    constant_names =        'sig_H    sig_L     kB'       
    constant_expressions =  '1.0e-6   9.4e-5 8.617e-5' #[1/(ohm*nm)] [1/(ohm*nm)] [eV/K]
    expression = 'if(N<0, sig_H*exp(-E_AC_elec/(kB*T)), if(N>${Nmax}, sig_L*exp(-E_AC_elec/(kB*T)),((sig_L-sig_H)/${Nmax}*N+sig_H)*exp(-E_AC_elec/(kB*T))))'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./sigma_PF]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables = 'N E_mag T'
    property_name = 'sigma_PF'
    constant_names =        ' sig_H    sig_L    a              b'       
    constant_expressions =  ' 1.0e-6   9.4e-5   5.48*sqrt(10)  -5.7'
    expression = 'if(N<0, sig_H*exp(293/T*(a*sqrt(E_mag)+b)), if(N>${Nmax}, sig_L*exp(293/T*(a*sqrt(E_mag)+b)),((sig_L-sig_H)/${Nmax}*N+sig_H)*exp(293/T*(a*sqrt(E_mag)+b))))'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./current_density_y]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'current_density'
    coupled_variables = 'Ey'
    material_property_names = 'electrical_conductivity'
    expression = 'electrical_conductivity*Ey'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]

  [./current_density_y_times_x]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'current_density_y_times_x'
    coupled_variables = 'dum_x'
    material_property_names = 'current_density'
    expression = 'current_density*dum_x'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]


  ############ Heat ############
  [./k_INS]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'thermal_conductivity'
    coupled_variables = 'N'
    constant_names =        'k_H      k_L'
    constant_expressions =  '0.12e-9  57.5e-9'
    expression = 'if(N<0, k_H, if(N>${Nmax}, k_L, (k_L-k_H)/${Nmax}*N+k_H))'    # W/(nm K)
#    expression = 'if(N<0, k_H, (k_L-k_H)/1.2*N+k_H)'    # W/(nm K)
    outputs = exodus
#    block = 2
  [../]

  ####################

[]

[AuxVariables]

  [dum_x]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []

  ########## Electric ##########
  [Ex]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  [Ey]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  [E_mag]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  [E_AC_elec]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []

  ######## Electric END ########

[]


[AuxKernels]

  [dummy]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = dum_x
    use_xyzt = true
    expression = 'x'
  []

  ########## Electric ##########
  [Ex_aux]
    type = PotentialToFieldAux
    variable = Ex
    gradient_variable = V
    sign = negative
    component = x
  []

  [Ey_aux]
    type = PotentialToFieldAux
    variable = Ey
    gradient_variable = V
    sign = negative
    component = y
  []

  [E_mag_aux]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = E_mag
    coupled_variables = 'Ex Ey'
    expression = 'sqrt(Ex^2+Ey^2)'
  []


  [E_AC_elec_aux]
    type = ParsedAux
    variable = E_AC_elec
    coupled_variables = 'N'
    constant_names = 'Nth  E_AC'
    constant_expressions = '5.0  0.05' #[nm^-3] [eV]
    expression = 'if(N>Nth, -0.006, if(N<0, E_AC, -E_AC/Nth*N + E_AC))'
    execute_on = 'initial linear timestep_end'
#    block = 2
  []

  ######## Electric END ########
[]

[Postprocessors]

  ######## Electric #######

  #  [./Resistance]
  #    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
  #    function = resistance_func
  #  [../]

  [average_V]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = V
#    boundary = 'trape2_top'
    boundary = 'top'
  []


  [Current_density_integral]
    type = SideIntegralMaterialProperty
#    boundary = 'BE_top'
    boundary = bottom

#    boundary = 'blk_bot'
    property = current_density_y_times_x
  []

  [Current]
    type = ParsedPostprocessor
    constant_names = 'pi'
    constant_expressions = '3.14'
    function = "if(Current_density_integral>0,Current_density_integral*2*pi,-Current_density_integral*2*pi)" 
    pp_names = Current_density_integral
  []

  ######## Electric END #######

  [Timestepsize]
    type = TimestepSize
  []

  [Max_T]
    type = NodalExtremeValue
    variable = T
  []

[]

[Debug]
  show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre      boomeramg'

  l_max_its = 50
  nl_max_its = 50

  l_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    growth_factor = 1.5
    cutback_factor = 0.5
    optimal_iterations = 5
    dt = 1e-4
  [../]
  
#  [./Adaptivity]
#    interval = 2
#    refine_fraction = 0.2
#    coarsen_fraction = 0.3
#    max_h_level = 3
#  [../]


  dtmin = 1e-13
  dtmax = 2.5e-2

  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 1.5

########## For TEST ##########
#  num_steps = 2
##############################


  automatic_scaling = true
#  compute_scaling_once = false
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
  file_base = output

  [myexo]
    type = Exodus
    file_base = half
    interval = 2
#    start_step = 4340 
  []

  [mymycp]
    type = Checkpoint
    num_files = 10
    interval = 50
    file_base = mycp
  []
[]

I don't know why. Maybe subdomainblock or Meshrefinement has some issues on this problems?
Thank you
Best Wishes,
Jeonghwan Jang

Hello
why do you say mesh refinement may have an issue? The Adaptivity block seems to be commented out
is this a recent version of moose? These initial conditions were not block restricted last year
Guillaume

Hello.

why do you say mesh refinement may have an issue? The Adaptivity block seems to be commented out

It is just my naive guess. I tried to find some differences with my coworker's file and the differences were only existence of the subdomainblock and refinement of it like below.
  [./refine_0]
    type = RefineBlockGenerator
    input = blk1
    block = 0
    refinement = '5'
  [../]

I am not using the latest version. I downloaded it this year on Feb.
But I am curious about the reason why SmoothCircleIC of my coworker's input file works well, while SmoothCircleIC of mine doesn't, even though I simulated both files using the same version of MOOSE.
if you remove refinement do you get the right values?

Yes. It works.
I think I must not use the refinement.
I made several blocks and set different nx and ny.
Anyway, Thanks for your help. I hope you guys fix this problem soon, if you guys think it is a crucial matter.

Hello
I investigated this and the issue is that the SubdomainBoundingBox generator does not convert refined elements to the right block.
So you end up with holes in that little region that is created from a refined area.
One solution for now (until we fix it) is to re-organize the blocks:
[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 60
    ny = 70
    xmin = 0
    xmax = ${xmax}
    ymin = 0
    ymax = ${ymax}
    zmin = 0
    zmax = 0
    elem_type = QUAD4
  []
  [blk1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 1                                                                                                                                                                                bottom_left = '0.0  0.000  0.0'
    top_right = '${xmax} 30.00000  0.0'
    block_name = 'reservoir'
    input = gen
  []

  [blk2]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    block_id = 2
    bottom_left = '10.00  30.00  0.0'
    top_right = '20.00 35.00  0.0'
    block_name = 'filament'
    input = blk1
  []

  [refine_0]
    type = RefineBlockGenerator
    input = blk2
    block = '0 2'
    refinement = '2 2'
  []

  [bd1]
    type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
    block = 1
    new_boundary = 'interface'
    normal = '0 1 0'
    input = refine_0
  []

Guillaume

I see!
Thanks for your passion and kindness!

node.title: J-integral calculation for a 2D edge crack with collapse nodes at the crack tip
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am using the tensor mechanics module to calculate J-integral for a 2D edge crack with collapse nodes at the crack tip.
I'm following the example in
~\moose\modules\tensor_mechanics\test\tests\j_integral\j_integral_2d.i
The J-integral result at 50% through the width is shown below.

I'm trying to follow this example to calculate J-integral for a 2D edge crack with collapse nodes at the crack tip. Figures of the 2D edge crack with web mesh are shown below.


However, when I tried running the model, I got an error message about the "CrackFrontDefinition", shown below.

I tried selecting 1 of the collapse nodes at the crack tip. I also tried selecting all the collapse nodes. And, I still get the same error.
My input file is below.
[GlobalParams]
  order = FIRST
  family = LAGRANGE
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  volumetric_locking_correction = true
[]

[Mesh]
  file = edge_crack_2d.e
  # use_displaced_mesh = false
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./SED]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./master]
    strain = SMALL
    add_variables = true
    incremental = false
    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_zz vonmises_stress'
    planar_formulation = PLANE_STRAIN
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./SED]
    type = MaterialRealAux
    variable = SED
    property = strain_energy_density
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
  [./rampConstant]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0. 1.'
    y = '0. 1.'
    scale_factor = -1
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./Pressure]
    [./top_edge]
      boundary = 'topEdge'
      function = rampConstant
    [../]
  [../]

  [./crack_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'botEdge'
    value = 0.0
  [../]

  [./pin_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'pinNode'
    value = 0.0
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 207000
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  [../]
  [./elastic_stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  [../]
[]

[DomainIntegral]
  integrals = JIntegral
  boundary = 'crackNode'
  crack_direction_method = CrackDirectionVector
  crack_direction_vector = '1 0 0'
  2d = true
  axis_2d = 2
  radius_inner = '0.501 0.505 0.510 0.515'
  radius_outer = '0.505 0.510 0.515 0.520'
  output_q = false
  incremental = false
[]



[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = '101'

  line_search = 'none'

  l_max_its = 50
  nl_max_its = 20
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-12
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  l_tol = 1e-2

  start_time = 0.0
  dt = 1

  end_time = 1
  num_steps = 1
[]

[Outputs]
  file_base = j_integral_edge_crack_2d
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

Hello
can you plot only the ‘crackNode’ boundary in paraview to check that it meets the conditions?
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Below is the 'crackNode' boundary plot.

I'm not quite sure what the conditions that need to be met are. Could you please provide a bit more detail on those conditions?
Minh
The error message says the nodes should be aligned. How many nodes does « crackNode » have? And are they aligned? If it s all the nodes in the picture then they are not obviously
Actually, if run you input with --mesh-only on the command line, the output to console should describe crackNode enough (the bounding box will be flat if all the nodes are aligned here)

It turns out that in the 'boundary' option accepts node set ID, not node set name. Please see below. The mesh seems fine. The code runs now. Thank you for the pointer, Guillaume.
[DomainIntegral]
  integrals = JIntegral
  boundary = 5000
  crack_direction_method = CrackDirectionVector
  crack_direction_vector = '1 0 0'
  2d = true
  axis_2d = 2
  radius_inner = '0.501 0.505 0.510 0.515 0.520 0.525'
  radius_outer = '0.505 0.510 0.515 0.520 0.525 0.530'
  output_q = false
  incremental = false
[]

node.title: Use several different custom interpolation functions simultaneously
node.bodyText: In the finite element, the interpolation function (test function) is very important, especially in some algorithms, the selection of the interpolation function directly affects the results of the algorithm. At present, I want to use multiple interpolation functions in the same formula. So how do you use multiple interpolating functions in an equation at the same time (even scalar interpolating functions and vector interpolating functions at the same time)? If there is a way or a similar example, I would appreciate your help
Can you be more specific about what kind of discretization you want to perform? We do things like Streamline-Upwind Petrov-Galerkin in several places in the repository

Thanks for your reply. I had some difficulties with moose's interpolation functions, first I wanted to use both vector and scalar functions to dediscretize equations, and to custom-build Jacobian matrices and residuals (both interpolation functions are used). But I don't know how to use this algorithm in moose, so I'd like to check if there are any good suggestions
That's not very clear to me. Do you have multiple physics? What are they?

This is because the weak form I use comes from an algorithm:
I have a current continuity equation: ∇ jn-∂ n/∂t-Rn=0, where Jn is the current density, n is the carrier concentration, and Rn is the net recombination velocity. In the steady state case, this equation becomes ∇ Jn-Rn =0, then use Jn = W (j) *Jn (j), where W is the vector interpolation function, then i use Ni as the scalar test function, then the equation becomes: N (i) *∇ (W (j) *Jn (j)) -Ni *Rn =0. Therefore, I want to use both interpolation functions at the same time, and whether moose is capable of handling this situation

This is just an example that I'm giving you to show you my discretization, you don't have to think about the rationality of this algorithm, just to show why I want two different kinds of interpolation functions to be used at the same time, right
I'll think about the rationality of it as I see fit for answering the questions you are asking

By "two different kinds of interpolation functions" do you mean different Finite Element spaces?  You can certainly have both a vector-valued and a scalar-valued variable coupled into the same system of equations (though vector-valued spaces are tricky enough that in general users tend to construct them from tensor products of scalar spaces unless they have some special needs like Nedelec elements where the space can't be decomposed that way).
Or are you trying to talk about Petrov-Galerkin methods?  Your question here is really hard to parse.

To add on to @roystgnr's comment, we do have examples of multiple-variable systems with multiple finite element types (one being scalar, and another being vector). One example is here: https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/kernels/vector_fe/coupled_scalar_vector.i
